body_content.explanation: a disease that killed an extremely large number of people in Europe and Asia in the 14th century, usually thought to be a form of bubonic plague, a very infectious disease caused by bacteria spread mainly by fleas (=small insects that bite) on rats or other animals, that causes swelling, fever, and usually death in humans :
examples: In the 14th century, crop failures, war, and the onset of the Black Death all reduced the population by between a half and a third.
In the period following the Black Death there was an acute shortage of labour.
